div1.head: Newspaper clipping, [September 1925]
div1.p:
Dr. Henry Carter, Who Died
Recently, Led In Medical
and Sanitary Fields

Dr. Henry R. Carter, former assist-
ant surgeon general of the United
States Public Health Service, who
died in Washington last week at the
age of 73, was in charge of the public
health service in Norfolk 25 years
ago. Many older residents here re-
member him and his work in Norfolk.

He was considered one of the
leading medical and sanitary special-
ists in the country and won fame
through the demonstration of new
principles and the application of
them to practical results. It was his
work which was responsible for the
determination of the period of ex-
trinsic incubation of yellow fever and
he founded the present maritime
quarantine system of the United
States.

Other measures, notably the curb-
ing of malaria, added to his prestige
and he was associated closely with
General Gorgas and Col. Walter Reed
in their investigation. He had a
great deal of practical experience in
combating the diseases of the tropics.

He was a native of Caroline
County and was buried at Ashland,
Va., beside his wife, who died a few
years ago.
